div1.p: UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION
In the Matter of the Application of LEWIS JOHNSON, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus. } No.3077.
RETURN.

Comes now John M. Boyle, United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington, and makes his return to the petition for a writ of habeas corpus in the above entitled cause by Winter S. Martin, Assistant United States Attorney for the said district, and thereupon your respondent replies, alleges and avers as follows:

That the respondent is without sufficient informa- tion to make answer to the allegation of citizenship of the said Lewis Johnson, and therefore requires the peti- tioner to prove the same, if the said fact be material to the issue raised herein.
-II-
Respondent admits the second paragraph of the peti- tion.
-III-

Respondent admits all the matters and things charged in paragraph three of the petition concerning the cause of detention of the petitioner by the respondent, except that petitioner is held upon irregular, illegal and void process in said cause, and as to said fact of illegal
detention denies the same.
-IV-
Respondent denies the last paragraph of the the petition.
AS AN AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE SAID RESPONDENT ALLEGES:

That on the 22nd day of June, A.D. 1915, John K. Kennedy, Barrister at Law for the city of Vancouver, in the Province of British Columbia, and Crown Prosecutor for the said city, appeared before the Honorable John C. Whitlock, United States Commissioner in and for the said Western District of Washington, in the Northern Division thereof, at Seattle, and made oath to a complaint in affidavit form, a copy of which is attached hereto and marked exhibit "A" of this return. That immediately thereafter and in pursuance thereof, the said John C. Whitlock issued his warrant of arrest for the said defend- ant, who was then confined in the city jail in the city of Seattle, under process which had theretofore issued by the state of Washington, charging the defendant then and theretofore with having brought stolen property into the United States and into King County in said state. That said warrant of arrest was served upon the said defendant- petitioner, and thereafter he was brought before the said John C. Witlock, United States Commissioner, to answer the complaint of the said John K. Kennedy.
-II-

That during the hearing of the said cause before said Commissioner, John K. Kennedy was duly sworn as a witness and offered evidence under oath concerning his authority
to represent the Dominion of Canada for the extradition and return of the petitioner to Vancouver, in the Province of British Columbia, in said Dominion, upon the charge of larceny committed at said Vancouver, as set forth in the complaint. That after evidence showing his authority to represent said Dominion of Canada had been offered, there was then introduced at said hearing depositions of certain witnesses whose testimony had been taken before a Police Magistrate in the city of Vancouver, which said depositions were in due form, under oath before the said Police Magis- trate, at said Vancouver, and thereafter duly authenticated and visaed by the proper consular officers, all as required by Section 5271 of the Revised Statutes of the United States. That thereafter testimony was offered by William McRae, Deputy Police Constable of said Vancouver, to identify the said Lewis Johnson, then and there before the Commissioner, as the Lewis Johnson mentioned in the depo- sitions taken at Vancouver aforesaid. That thereupon the demanding government rested its case, and the defendant having then and there the opportunity to produce evidence in his own behalf, and then and there being represented by counsel, failed to offer any evidence to refute or con- tradict the evidence offered by the said Dominion of Can- ada, and thereupon the said John C. Whitlock, United States Commissioner, found probable cause to hold the said Lewis Johnson to await the action of the Secretary of State of the United States, all as provided under Section 5270 of the Revised Statutes of the United States.
-III- That thereafter the evidence taken before the said

Commissioner was transcribed and typewritten, and attached to the original depositions, duly authenticated as afore- said, and forwarded to the Secretary of State of the United States, under the hand and seal of the said United States Commissioner, duly certifying to the said Secretary of State that the said document contained all the evidence submitted in said cause before him. That copies of the said United States Commissioner's certificates are hereto attached and marked exhibits "B" and "C" of this return.
-IV-

That a copy of the transcript of the oral testimony is available at this time for the purpose of this hearing, but the duly authenticated despositions of the witnesses in British Columbia, concering the facts of the larceny, have been forwarded to the Secretary of State, at Washing- ton, D.C., all as required by said Section 5270 of the Revised Statutes, and unless copies of these depositions can be used in lieu of said originals, it will be necessary to await the decision of the Secretary of State, if this Honorable Court deems it necessary to produce said original documents upon the hearing of this petition.

That immediately upon finding probable cause to hold the said Lewis Johnson, said John C. Whitlock, United States Commissioner, issued his final mittimus remanding the prisoner, Lewis Johnson, to the King County Jail, to await the action of the Secretary of State of the United States, all as required by said Section 5270 of the Revised Statutes, and respondent alleges that all and singular the proceedings in the matter of the detention of Lewis Johnson,

a fugitive from justice from the city of Vancouver, charged with an extraditable crime committed at said Vancouver, were regular and proper, and the defendant lawfully com- mitted to custody thereunder.
WHEREFORE, your respondent having duly answered to said writ, prays that the same may be dismissed, and that he have and recover his costs, fees and disbursements herein.
Winter S. Martin Attorney for Respondent.
THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION } ss.
Winter S. Martin being first duly sworn on oath, deposes and says
